case_name: Kirloskar Oil Engines Ltd. v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 587 of 1960 is an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 587 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the award dated December 16, 1958, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I. T.  No. 387 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal arises from award dated December 16, 1958 of Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in Reference I.T. No. 387 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the award dated December 16, 1958, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference  I. T.  No. 387 of 1958. C. Setalvad, Attorney-General of India and N. Shroff, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant is Kirloskar Oil Engines Ltd., Kirkee, Poona.

anchor.surface_text: the proceedings taken at the instance of the appellant, the Kirloskar Oil Engines Ltd., Kirkee, Poona under s. 36A of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  14 of 1947   hereafter called the Act .

facts.text: Certain disputes pending between appellant and respondents (workmen) referred to industrial tribunal by Government of Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that certain disputes pending between the appellant and the respondents, its workmen, were referred to the industrial tribunal for its adjudication by the Government of Maharashtra.

facts.text: Disputes related to seven demands, two regarding privilege leave and allowances.

anchor.surface_text: The disputes in question related to seven demands made by the respondents two of these were in regard to privilege leave and allowances.

facts.text: Part I of award dealing with privilege leave and allowances made on June 30, 1958, published on July 7, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Part I of the award which dealt the demand of privilege leave and different kinds of allowances was made on June 30, 1958, and published on July 7, 1958.

facts.text: Appellant applied to State Government on August 2, 1958 for reference under s. 36A for clarification on privilege leave and allowances.

anchor.surface_text: On August 2, 1958, the appellant applied to the State Government for reference of certain points to the tribunal for its clarification under s. 36A.

facts.text: Order of reference made under s. 36A in respect of privilege leave and allowances.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly an order of reference was made in respect of the two items privilege leave and allowances.

facts.text: Tribunal clarified privilege leave direction: workmen must put in 240 days actual working in previous year per s.79 Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, in regard to the provision made by the award as to privilege leave the clarification claimed by the appellant was made. In regard to the second point on which clarification was sought the relevant direction in the award reads thus

facts.text: Original award para 10 directed 15 days privilege leave to all workmen, accumulable up to 45 days.

anchor.surface_text: All the workmen, both daily and monthly rated, get privilege leave according to the provisions of the Factories Act. The leave usually companyes to 14 or 15 days in a year I companysider a privilege leave of 15 days a year to both the sections of the workmen in the Kirloskar oil Engines as quite adequate.

facts.text: Appellant apprehended award para 10 allows 15 days leave even without actual attendance, if on muster roll.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant apprehended that the direction of the award may justify a claim by every worker whose name is on the muster roll to 15 days privilege leave irrespective of his actual attendance during the year.

facts.text: Award para 14 directs: work on weekly off or holiday (paid/unpaid) gets 1 1/2 times wages and DA over substituted holiday.

anchor.surface_text: I therefore direct that if a workman has to work on a weekly off or on a holiday  paid or unpaid  he should be paid 1 1/2 times his wages and dearness allowance over and above substituted holiday.

facts.text: Tribunal refused clarification on para 14, held it clear, no modification under s.36A.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal held that the direction itself was very clear and that under the guise of clarification the appellant was seeking its modification. So the tribunal rejected the appellants claim for any clarification in that behalf.

facts.text: In 1956 and 1957, State Government compelled factories to change weekly holidays from Sunday due to shortage of electrical energy.

anchor.surface_text: The grievance of the appellant in substance is that in 1956 and 1957, on account of shortage of electrical energy for industrial purposes the State Government companypelled the factories to change their weekly holidays from Sunday to some other week day,

facts.text: Judgment delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J. on November 17, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. November 17. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-This appeal by special leave arises out of the proceedings taken at the instance of the appellant,

facts.text: Under s.79 Factories Act 1948, worker entitled to leave only if worked 240 days or more in calendar year.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that under s. 79 of the Factories Act 1948, it is only where a worker has worked for a period of 240 days or more in a factory during a calendar year that he becomes entitled during the subsequent calendar year to leave with wages

facts.text: Appellant argued before tribunal that para 14 imposes heavy burden when whole factory works on weekly off due to power shortage orders.

anchor.surface_text: each factory or group of factories observing one week day as weekly off. According to the appellant, if a handful of workmen are to work on a weekly off or on a holiday when the whole factory is closed then there would be some justification for making the payment

facts.text: Tribunal noted argument on power shortage not raised in original proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: It is significant that the argument based on the orders issued by the State Government requiring the factories to change their weekly holidays owing to shortage of electric energy was number raised before the tribunal at the time when it originally heard the dispute

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.36A limited to interpretation, not merits or modification of award.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that the scope of the enquiry under s. 36A is limited to the decision of the difficulties or doubts arising as to the interpretation of any provision in the award. If the words used in any provision of an award are ambiguous or obscure

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appellant's contention on accumulation of privilege leave up to 45 days as not raised before tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeal the learned Attorney- General attempted to argue that the accumulation of privilege leave up to 45 days allowed by the award was number justified. In our opinion, this argument cannot be entertained in the present appeal for two reasons.

facts.text: Tribunal's refusal to clarify para 14 upheld by Supreme Court as provision clear, no ambiguity.

anchor.surface_text: Quite clearly the impugned provisions companytained in paragraph 14 of the award in relation to this demand are clear and unambiguous. Whatever may be the appellants grievance in respect of the validity or the propriety of the said directions there is numberdifficulty or doubt about their meaning

facts.text: Appellant could have declared another day as first day of week under s.52 Factories Act.

anchor.surface_text: Besides the tribunal has observed that having regard to the definition of the word week under s. 2  f  of the Factories Act as well as the provisions of s. 52 of the said Act it would have been open to the appellant to have another day of the week declared

under Art. 136 of the Constitution, to this Court. A grievance felt by a party against any provision of the award can be ventilated only in that way and not by adopting the procedure prescribed by s. 36A.

arguments.claim: Paragraph 14 provisions clear and unambiguous; tribunal right in refusing clarification

anchor.surface_text: Quite clearly the impugned provisions contained in paragraph 14 of the award in relation to this demand are clear and unambiguous. Whatever may be the appellants grievance in respect of the validity or the propriety of the said directions there is no difficulty or doubt about their meaning

holdings.text: The scope of the enquiry under s. 36A is limited to the decision of the difficulties or doubts arising as to the interpretation of any provision in the award. If the words used in any provision of an award are ambiguous or obscure and it is not reasonably possible to interpret them the difficulty arising from the use of such ambiguous or obscure words may be resolved by moving the appropriate Government to make a reference under s. 36A. It is obvious that any question about the propriety, correctness or validity of any provision of the award would be outside the purview of the enquiry contemplated by the section.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that the scope of the enquiry under s. 36A is limited to the decision of the difficulties or doubts arising as to the interpretation of any provision in the award. If the words used in any provision of an award are ambiguous or obscure

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.36A empowers government to refer only interpretation doubts; tribunal decides after hearing, final; excludes merits, propriety or validity which require appeal under Art.136.

holdings.text: The argument that the accumulation of privilege leave up to 45 days allowed by the award was not justified cannot be entertained in the present appeal because no such plea was made before the tribunal and it falls outside the limitations of the enquiry under s.36A.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeal the learned Attorney- General attempted to argue that the accumulation of privilege leave up to 45 days allowed by the award was not justified. In our opinion, this argument cannot be entertained in the present appeal for two reasons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea not raised in clarification proceedings before tribunal; s.36A confines enquiry to interpretation, not propriety of award provisions; even if raised, tribunal justified in refusing.

holdings.text: The provisions contained in paragraph 14 of the award are clear and unambiguous; there is no difficulty or doubt about their meaning; the tribunal was right in refusing to alter the said direction in the present proceedings under s.36A.

anchor.surface_text: Quite clearly the impugned provisions contained in paragraph 14 of the award in relation to this demand are clear and unambiguous. Whatever may be the appellants grievance in respect of the validity or the propriety of the said directions there is no difficulty or doubt about their meaning

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual clarity in para 14 direction for 1 1/2 times pay plus substituted holiday; appellant's power shortage and burden arguments seek modification of merits, not interpretation clarification under s.36A.

holdings.text: A proceeding contemplated by s. 36A is not a proceeding intended to enable the tribunal to review or modify its own order; it is intended to enable the tribunal only to clarify the provisions of its award where a difficulty or doubt arises about the interpretation of the provisions.

anchor.surface_text: A proceeding contemplated by s. 36A is not a proceeding intended to enable the tribunal to review or modify its own order it is intended to enable the tribunal only to clarify the provisions of its award where a difficulty or doubt arises about the interpretation of the provisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reinforces s.36A's purpose as clarification only, distinguishing from review; applied to reject para 14 modification claim.

holdings.text: If a party to the award is aggrieved by any of its provisions on the merits the only remedy available to it is by making an appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution to this Court and not by adopting the procedure prescribed by s. 36A.

anchor.surface_text: If a party to the award is aggrieved by any of its provisions on the merits the only remedy available to it is by making an appeal, say for instance under Art. 136 of the Constitution, to this Court. A grievance felt by a party against any provision of the award can be ventilated only in that way and not by adopting the procedure prescribed by s. 36A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes remedies: s.36A for interpretation, constitutional appeal for merits challenges.

anchor.surface_text: If a party to the award is aggrieved by any of its provisions on the merits the only remedy available to it is by making an appeal, say for instance under Art. 136 of the Constitution, to this Court. A grievance felt by a party against any provision of the award can be ventilated only in that way and not by adopting the procedure prescribed by s. 36A.
